content: November - Latvian National Council proclaims independence.
- Civil war ends in peace treaty with Soviet Russia.
- Prime minister Karlis Ulmanis seizes power following succession of unstable governments.
- Soviet Union annexes Latvia, along with neighbouring Estonia and Latvia. Mass deportations to Siberia and Central Asia.
- Nazi Germany invades. Some 70,000 Latvian Jews are killed by Nazi death squads and Latvian paramilitary units.
- Soviet Army returns, heralding further waves of deportations and repression of resistance to Soviet rule.
- First major anti-Soviet demonstrations held by nationalist and environmental activists.
March - Referendum produces large majority in favour of independence.
August - During the attempted anti-Gorbachev coup in Moscow, Omon forces again strike in Riga, causing another six deaths. Parliament declares the full restoration of independence.
November - Citizenship law passed, giving citizenship to those who held it before Soviet occupation of 1940 and their descendants.
July - Guntis Ulmanis elected president.
August - Last Russian troops leave.
- Vaira Vike-Freiberga is elected president - the first woman president in eastern Europe.
May - Parliament votes to change election law in a bid to boost Nato membership chances, omitting clause requiring parliamentary candidates to be able to speak Latvian.
September - Latvian referendum vote gives strong backing to EU membership.
March - Latvia joins Nato.
May - Latvia is one of 10 new states joining the European Union.
August - New citizenship law requires applicants to pass Latvian language test.
December - International Monetary Fund (IMF) approves 1.68bn euro rescue package to help Latvia ride out severe economic slump.
January - Hundreds of demonstrators clash with police in Riga as anti-government protests over the terms of the IMF rescue package turn violent.
January - Unemployment soars to 20%, giving Latvia the highest jobless rate in the EU.
September - Pro-Russian Harmony Centre emerges as largest party in snap elections, but coalition government excludes it.
February - Referendum on giving Russian joint official language status rejected by a large margin.
January - Latvia joins the eurozone.
September - US President Barack Obama visits Estonia to reassure the Baltic states that they can count on Nato protection, amid tensions following Russia's seizure of Crimea.
October - Centre-right coalition wins a clear majority in parliamentary elections dominated by concern about Russia's intervention in Ukraine and its influence in the Baltic region.
March - Nato reinforces its presence in the Baltic states and its forces conduct major military drills in the region.

January - Arturs Krisjanis Karins becomse prime minister of a centre-right coalition, excluding the pro-Russia Harmony party that had emerged as the largest bloc after October 2018 parliamentary elections.
February - Russia invades Ukraine
August - Latvia declares state of emergency along its border with Belarus over sharp climb in illegal border-crossing attempts.
